svn path=/trunk/kdeedu/kstars/; revision=179129

title: Portability fix for FreeBSD, probably needs fixing for other non-glibc systems too
message:
Portability fix for FreeBSD, probably needs fixing for other non-glibc systems too

I'm pretty sure this can be done with auto*, but it is beyond my skills.

From Jason's commit log (for the backport to KDE_3_0_BRANCH)
--
two performance backports:  Replaced dms::PI() with const double dms::PI.
We had been actually computing acos(-1) every time we needed PI (duh).
Now we just use the value defined in math.h.  Also, using sincos()
function defined in math.h in place of calling sin() and cos() separately
in dms::SinCos().  This is about 33% faster.  However, sincos() is not a
standard C/C++ function; it is defined in GNU C.  We may need to add a
contingency for non-Linux compiles...
--

This has just ensured that the Branch won't build for some people (me for a start, and I
am quite sure others too). Please consider reverting the sincos() stuff in the branch,
as I am not going to commit a partial fix there, just to sort out something that should
have been fully tested in HEAD before backporting.

CCMAIL: kstars@30doradus.org

diff -u -3 -p -r1.11 dms.cpp
--- dms.cpp     2002/09/19 11:52:57     1.11
+++ dms.cpp     2002/09/20 06:03:06
@@ -106,17 +106,21 @@ dms dms::operator- (dms angle)

 void dms::SinCos( double &sina, double &cosa ) {
 // This is the old implementation of sincos which is standard C compliant
+#if defined(__FreeBSD__)
+// almost certainly this needs more checks for other non-glibc platforms
+// but I am currently unable to check those
 /*
        register double rad = radians();
        sina = sin( rad );
        cosa = cos( rad );
 */
-
+#else
 /**The sincos function computes sin and cos at once (hardware accelareted / fsincos in assembler).
        *It's ~33% faster than computing sin and cos separate. But sincos() is not a standard C/C++
        *function and requires #define _GNU_SOURCE. It's defined in math.h.
        */
        sincos(radians(), &sina, &cosa);
+#endif
 }

svn path=/trunk/kdeedu/kstars/; revision=172210

title: reworked right-click popup menus.  There are now four different types of
message:
reworked right-click popup menus.  There are now four different types of
menus, depending on the type of object being clicked on (empty sky, star,
sky object, planet).  Each has its own "createXXXMenu" method.

Along the way, I uncovered and fixed a bug in ObjectNameList::first().  If
there was no object in the first group (objects beginning with a number),
then first() would return NULL.  It now goes to the next group (objects
beginning with "A") if mode==allLists.

includemocs.. in case anyone is interested, this script does all the work for you: for I in $(for I in *.h; do if grep Q_OBJECT $I >/dev/null 2>&1 && ! grep ${I/.h/.moc} ${I//.h/.cpp} >/dev/null 2>&1; then echo $I; fi ; done); do echo && echo "#include \"${I//.h/.moc}\"" >> ${I//.h/.cpp}; done

svn path=/trunk/kdeedu/kstars/; revision=160856

title: First implementation of the InfoBoxes, a lightweight replacement of the
message:
First implementation of the InfoBoxes, a lightweight replacement of the
infopanel.  These boxes are drawn directly on the SkyMap, instead of using
QLabels in a separate widget (this is quite a bit more efficient).  Also
the boxes are highly interactive: they can be dragged to any position in
the map (there is collision detection to ensure that the boxes don't
overlap or go off-screen); and they can be "shaded" to a compact,
single-line display by double-clicking.  Eventually, they will also be
hideable and have customizable colors.

svn path=/trunk/kdeedu/kstars/; revision=160663

title: changed dms::PI() from a function that calls acos(-1.0) to a static const
message:
changed dms::PI() from a function that calls acos(-1.0) to a static const
member variable.  This way, the acos(-1.0) calculation is performed only
once.  Since PI() was called in every instance of SinCos(), this is a
significant savings of CPU!  Replaced every instance of "PI()" with
"dms::PI".

svn path=/trunk/kdeedu/kstars/; revision=158487

title: minor bugfix: changed width of drawn lines to 1 (were: 0) in
message:

SkyMap::paintEvent().  This was necessary because on some systems, the
width 0 lines "flicker" and are drawn black most of the time (I think it
is a video card or X issue).  Anyway, setting line thickness to 1 solves
the problem, and I don't think it makes the lines appear any thicker.

svn path=/trunk/kdeedu/kstars/; revision=154494

title: Modified to get the rise and set time taking into account the new RA and
message:
Modified to get the rise and set time taking into account the new RA and
DEC coordinates of the object for the rise and set time. The procedure used
is iterative, but only uses one iteration. That is, it computes the UT
time for rise and set time, and recomputes the RA and DEC coordinates for
that time. With the new coordinates the rise and set time are computed again.

 There are some new functions, which have been made private to hide the
details of the iteration. The public ones are riseTime, setTime,
and riseUTTime and return the expected values for a given SkyObject object.

title: Rotated planet images now work under KDE2...I copied the QImage::xForm()…
message:
Rotated planet images now work under KDE2...I copied the QImage::xForm() function from Qt3 into KSPlanetBase::xFormImage().
Under KDE2, the TimeUnitBox is now given a fixed width of 20 pixels, since I couldn't figure out how to obtain the actual width of the spin buttons.
KSPlanetBase::updateCoords() now calls findPosition(), so it's analogous to the SkyObject version.
Fixed scaling of printed images; printing now works (please test).
Fixed interruption of long sky slews.
Added 2 Estonian cities contributed by Raul Metsma.
Changed checks against KDE_VERSION to QT_VERSION (someone else changed this at the same time!  resolved conflicts...)
This is a release candidate for KStars-0.9; please test

svn path=/trunk/kdeedu/kstars/; revision=151418

title: Added transit time computation and auxiliary functions for that. The new
message:
Added transit time computation and auxiliary functions for that. The new
algorith is also appliable to rise and set times, after checking this one
works fine. Currently these changes do not work because geo->lng() retrieves
no result ???.

 The new algorithm refines the computation taking into account:
 - atmospheric refraction at the horizon
 - size of large sources
 - better RA and DEC coordinates close to rise, transit and set time, obtained
   interpolating from 3 pair of coordinates.

svn path=/trunk/kdeedu/kstars/; revision=150049

title: Reworked variable timesteps.  We now allow a much wider range of timesteps (up…
message:
Reworked variable timesteps.  We now allow a much wider range of timesteps (up to +/- 100 years).  I also changed how large timesteps are handled: the SimClock timer is halted, and the Simulation time is advanced manually one step after updating and drawing the sky.  This allows precise control over the time displayed (for example, if the time step is one day, each image of the sky is exactly one day after the previous image).

I also added position angle rotation of the planets, but it currently simply aligns them along a line toward the ecliptic pole (which is close, but just an approximation).
